# Equations

This section describes the equations used in the Pacific Herring statistical catch-age (SCA) model.
Symbols and constants are described in Table \@ref(tab:variables).
These equations will not be included in the final document.

## Steady-state model age structured model

Pacific Herring steady-state age-structured model assuming
unequal vulnerability-at-age,
age-specific fecundity, and
Beverton-Holt recruitment.

### Parameters

For the steady-state condition of the model, we assume the parameter vector
\begin{equation}\label{eq:df1}
\Theta = \left(R_0,\,h,\,M\right)
\end{equation}
is unknown, and can be estimated by fitting the SCA model to data.
Note the following restrictions: $R_0 > 0$, $0.2 \leq h < 1.0$, and $M > 0$.
For a given set of growth maturity-at-age parameters $\Phi$ 
\begin{equation}\label{eq:df2}
\Phi = \left(l_{\infty,s},\,\acute{k}_s,\,t_{0,s},\,\acute{a}_s,\,
\acute{b}_s,\,\dot{a}_s,\,\dot{\gamma}_s,\,\hat{a}_k,\,\hat{\gamma}_k\right).
\end{equation}

### Age-schedule information

Growth is assumed to follow von Bertalanffy
\begin{equation}\label{eq:df3}
l_{a,s} = l\left(1-e^{\left(-k_s\left(a-t_{0,s}\right)\right)}\right),
\end{equation}
mean weight-at-age is given by the allometric relationship
\begin{equation}\label{eq:df4}
w_{a,s} = \acute{a}_s\left(l_{a,s}\right)^{\acute{b}_s},
\end{equation}
and age-specific vulnerability is given by an age-based logistic function
\begin{equation}\label{eq:df5}
v_a = \left(1+e^{\left(\frac{-\left(\hat{a}-a\right)}{\hat{\gamma}}\right)}\right)^{-1}.
\end{equation}

The terms vulnerability and selectivity are used interchangeably throughout this document, although, technically,
selectivity refers to the fishing gear, while
vulnerability refers to all processes affecting the availability of fish to the fishery.
Selectivity parameters can be fixed or estimated.

Survivorship for unfished and fished populations is defined by Eq. 7 and 8, respectively.
It is assumed that all individuals ages A and older (i.e., the plus group) have the same total mortality rate.
The incidence functions refer to the life-time or per-recruit quantities such as spawning biomass per recruit (phi_E, Eq. 9) or vulnerable biomass per recruit (phi_B, Eq. 10).
Note that upper and lower case subscripts denote unfished and fished conditions, respectively.
Unfished spawning biomass is given by Eq. 11,
and the recruitment compensation ratio (Myers et al., 1999) is given by Eq. 12.
The steady-state equilibrium recruitment for a given fishing mortality rate Fe is given by Eq. 13.

\begin{equation}\label{eq:df6}
f_{a,s}=w_{a,s}\left(1+e^{\left(\frac{-\left(\dot{a}_s-a_s\right)}
{\dot{\gamma}_s}\right)}\right)^{-1}
\end{equation}

### Survivorship

\begin{equation}\label{eq:df7}
\iota_a = \begin{cases}
\frac{1}{S}, & a=1\\
\iota_{a-1}e^{-M}, & 1<a<A\\
\frac{\iota_{a-1}}{\left(1-e^{-M}\right)}, & a=A\\
\end{cases}
\end{equation}

\begin{equation}\label{eq:df8}
\iota_a = \begin{cases}
\frac{1}{S}, & a=1\\
\hat{\iota}_{a-1,s}e^{-M-F_ev_{a-1,s}}, & 1<a<A\\
\frac{\hat{\iota}_{a-1,s}e^{-M-F_ev_{a-1,s}}}{1-e^{-M-F_e v_{a,s}}}, & a=A\\
\end{cases}
\end{equation}

### Incidence functions

\begin{equation}\label{eq:phi_E}
\phi_E = \sum_{s=1}^S\sum_{a=1}^\infty \iota_a f_{a,s}
\end{equation}

\begin{equation}\label{eq:phi_e}
\phi_e = \sum_{s=1}^S\sum_{a=1}^\infty \hat{\iota}_{a,s} f_{a,s}
\end{equation}

\begin{equation}\label{eq:phi_B}
\phi_B = \sum_{s=1}^S\sum_{a=1}^\infty \iota_a w_{a,s} v_{a,s}
\end{equation}

\begin{equation}\label{eq:phi_b}
\phi_b = \sum_{s=1}^S\sum_{a=1}^\infty \hat{\iota}_{a,s} w_{a,s} v_{a,s}
\end{equation}

\begin{equation}\label{eq:phi_q}
\phi_q = \sum_{s=1}^S\sum_{a=1}^\infty
\frac{\hat{\iota}_{a,s} w_{a,s} v_{a,s}}{M+F_ev_{a,s}}
\left(1-e^{\left(-M-F_ev_{a,s}\right)}\right)
\end{equation}

\begin{equation}\label{eq:df12}
\mli{SB}_0 = R_0\phi_B
\end{equation}

\begin{equation}\label{eq:df13}
\kappa=\frac{4h}{1-h}
\end{equation}

Beverton-Holt recruitment
Note that we assume that recruitment follows a Beverton-Holt stock recruitment model,
where the maximum juvenile survival rate alpha is given by:

and the density-dependent term beta is given by:

which simplifes to Eq.D.14.
\begin{equation}\label{eq:df14}
R_e = R_0 \frac{\kappa-\frac{\phi_E}{\phi_e}}{\kappa-1}  
\end{equation}

The equilibrium yield Ce foragiven fshing mortality rate is given by Eq.15. 
\begin{equation}\label{eq:df15}
C_e = F_e R_e \phi_q
\end{equation}

 
These steady-state conditions are critical for determining various reference points such as FMSY and BMSY.


## Catch-age-model

Pacific herring statistical catch-age model using Baranov catch.

### Estimated parameters

\begin{equation}\label{eq:df16}
\Theta = \left(R_0,\,h,\,M,\,\overline{R},\,\overline{R}_{\mli{init}},\,\vartheta^2,\,\rho,\,
\Gamma_{k,t},\,\{\omega_t\}_{\acute{t}=1-A}^{\acute{t}=T},\,
\{\omega_{\mli{init},t}\}_{t=\acute{t}-A}^{t=\acute{t}-1}\right)
\end{equation}

\begin{equation}\label{eq:sigma}
\sigma = \sqrt{\rho}\vartheta
\end{equation}

\begin{equation}\label{eq:tau}
\tau = \sqrt{\left(1-\rho\right)}\vartheta  
\end{equation}

### Unobserved states

\begin{equation}\label{eq:N_tas}
N_{t,a,s}
\end{equation}

\begin{equation}\label{eq:SB_ts}
\mli{SB}_{t,s}
\end{equation}

\begin{equation}\label{eq:Z_tas}
Z_{t,a,s}
\end{equation}

### Initial states

\begin{equation}\label{eq:df19}
N_{t,a,s} = \frac{1}{S}\overline{R}_\mli{init}e^{\omega_{\mli{init},t}}e^{-M\left(a-1\right)}
\end{equation}

where $(\acute{t}-A) < t < 1$, and $2 \leq a \leq A$.   
 
\begin{equation}\label{eq:df20}
N_{t,a,s} = \frac{1}{S}\bar{R}e^{\omega_{t}}
\end{equation}

where $1 \leq t \leq T$, and $a = 1$.  

\begin{equation}\label{eq:df21}
v_{k,a} = \frac{1}{1+e^{-\frac{\left(a - \hat{a}_k\right)}{\hat{\gamma}_k}}}  
\end{equation}

\begin{equation}\label{eq:df22}
F_{k,t} = e^{\Gamma_{k,t}}
\end{equation}

### State dynamics ($t>1$)

\begin{equation}\label{eq:df23}
\mli{SB}_{t,s} = \sum_a N_{t,a,s}f_{a,s}
\end{equation}

\begin{equation}\label{eq:df24}
Z_{t,a,s} = M+\sum_k F_{k,t} v_{k,t,a,s}
\end{equation}

\begin{equation}\label{eq:df25}
\hat{C}_{k,t} = \sum_s \sum_a \frac {N_{t,a,s}w_{a,s}F_{k,t}
v_{k,t,a,s} \left( 1-{e^{-Z_{t,a,s}}} \right) }{Z_{t,a,s}}^{\eta_t}
\end{equation}

\begin{equation}\label{eq:df26}
N_{t,a,s} = \begin{cases}
\frac{\alpha E_{t-1}}{1+\beta E_{t-1}} e^{\left(\omega_t-0.5\tau^2\right)}, & a=1\\
N_{t-1,a-1,s} e^{\left(-Z_{t-1,a-1,s}\right)}, & 1<a<A\\
N_{t-1,a,s} e^{\left(-Z_{t-1,a,s}\right)}, & a=A\\
\end{cases}
\end{equation}

### Beverton-Holt recruitment model

\begin{equation}\label{eq:df27}
R_t = \frac{\alpha\mli{SB}_{t-k}}{1+\beta \mli{SB}_{t-k}}e^{\delta_{t}-0.5\tau^2}
\end{equation}
